titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. IV:30. Monday.— I came home with a Resolution to make an effort to employ my time more usefully this Summer than I have heretofore done and particularly to discharge more faithfully my duty to my father— But I can take no self-satisfaction from the success or more properly the failure of this day— I rose early but only redeemed the last arrears of my diary. A cold morning shower kept me before breakfast from the garden, and at breakfast we had fire in the parlour. The sky afterwards cleared away for the Sun, with Summer heat. My Mount Wollaston Tenant Alpheus Spear came only to promise that he would come again next week on Tuesday. Mr Carr settled with me for his rent to the first of April and asked me questions about Mr Poindexter. He said General Jackson’s friends here pretended that the reason why Lawrence’s pistols did not shoot Jackson was that he could not be shot— The Rev’d Mr Whitney and his Son Augustus paid me a morning visit, and Mr Durand with Mr Luman Read
were here after dinner. They came about the double collection of Portraits of the Presidents, which Mr Read has employed Durand to paint for him— One of which he intends to present to some public national institution, and the other he proposes to keep, himself— I lent Mr Durand the Portrait of my father, painted by Stuart in 1799 for him to copy, and I promised to sit to him next Thursday morning for another portrait of me— That which he painted of me at Washington two months ago, has been exhibited at New-York, at the annual exhibition, and was thought an excellent likeness— Durand has painted a copy of it for Mr Charles A. Davis, which he has presented to my Son Charles’s wife, and which is now at the Athenaeum exhibition in Boston. But instead of making another copy, Durand asked me to sit again to which I assented. I visited my garden in the heat of the day and planted Philadelphia maple seeds in Pot 1. and Washington maple-seeds in Pot 2.— The Pots have all but one been emptied by Rats and mice, or some other mischievous animal, and two or three of them are broken. Some of my Peach trees are dead—others dying— Weeds over run the whole garden, and my planting prospects are dismal—
2. IV.30. Tuesday.

I spent great part of this day in my garden and nursery, examining my seedling trees and plants— I began by planting a row of Philadelphia maple seeds, along under the Northern fence of my Eastern close. I scatter these seeds in various places without knowing whether any of them will vegetate— I had made much preparation last summer and autumn, for extending my plantations of nuts acorns and seeds of trees— In the midst of my experiments I was suddenly called away; my plantations were of course suspended, and another year has passed away leaving my purposes unperformed— Most especially the design of ascertaining the pedigree of my Seedling plants— That is, of identifying the plant that comes up with the nut, acorn or seed that was sown— I had sown in 18 earthenpots certain seeds, Stones and acorns of particular and valuable kinds— I had staked and stoned them, and made minutes of them in a Memorandum book. But the work was unfinished when I was called away. I directed that the Pots should be put into the cellar for the winter to preserve the Seeds from the hard frosts— They were so deposited; but Mrs Kirk who was left in the house when my wife went to Washington removed afterwards to Boston— My pots have remained in the cellar to this time without Sun or rain for two Months of the Spring— The rats and mice have half-emptied some of them, and there is only one of them in which several seedlings trees, which had come up in it last year seem yet to be alive but perishing— Makers of experiments which require years for solution must make up their minds to bear many disappointments without being discouraged— I had also planted several rows of Stones and seeds in the garden; which have all been dug up and lost, by a man who has been at work in it this Spring— A Stranger who knew not where my treasures were deposited, and thus uprooted them unwittingly— Many of my seedling plants of former years, however remain but their growth
after the first year is so slow, and imperceptible that I take little interest in them— Besides the time spent in my garden I lost some hours in searching all my books upon Astronomy, for a catalogue of fixed Stars of the first magnitude, and finally found one only in de la Lande— Mr Thomas Greenleaf and Mr Beale paid us Evening visits. Mr Beale requested me to preside at the dinner to-morrow at French’s tavern, to which I somewhat reluctantly consented; and Mr Greenleaf invited me to a party to-morrow Evening at his house to be given to the Ministers.
3. V:30. Wednesday.

At ten O’Clock this morning, on the ringing of the first Bell, I went to French’s Tavern, where were assembled the Ecclesiastical Council, for the installation of the Revd William Parsons Lunt, as Colleague Pastor to the Revd Peter Whitney over the first Congregational Church and Society at Quincy— The Revd. Doctor Thaddeus Mason Harris my classmate at Harvard University was Moderator of the Council, and was opening it with prayer— After which the names of the Churches and Societies were called over which had been invited to attend, at the solemnities of the day— They were numerous but were almost all present by their Pastors; and most of them by one lay delegate— The documents were then read by Mr John Whitney, of the invitation of the Church and Society to Mr Lunt to settle as the Colleague of Mr Whitney; and of his acceptance of the invitation, upon the terms proposed—a Salary of 800 dollars a year; and six Months notice to be given, if on either side a separation shall be desired— Dr Lowell then enquired if the documents were to be submitted to the Council relating to the dismission of Mr Lunt, from the office of Pastor to the second Unitarian Church and Society in the City of New-York; where he was for some time settled— To this, Mr Pierpont of Boston objected—maintaining that it was a matter with which the Council had no concern; and intimating that the besetting Sin of Ecclesiastical Councils in all ages had been usurpation of Jurisdiction— Then arose an ardent and somewhat sharp debate upon the question whether the papers should or should not be read; which was finally terminated by Mr Lunt himself’s requesting that they might be read, which they were. It appeared that the cause of his dismission from the New-York Congregation was their neglect to provide for his support—and the want of unanimity in his favour. He was dismissed at his own request, with a protest of a small number of the members of his congregation against the proceedings. The debate delayed the common consent of the Services more than a half an hour. It was near Noon, when the Procession preceded by the Committee of the Parish entered the Meeting-house— The order of the Services was 1. An Anthem— 2. Introductory prayer and Selections from Scripture by Revd. George Whitney of Roxbury. 3. A Hymn by Mr F. A. Whitney. 4. Sermon, by Revd. Mr Frothingham of Boston. 5. Prayer of Installation, by the Revd. Peter Whitney, Senior Pastor of the Church. 6. Charge by the Revd. Dr Francis
Parkman of Boston. 7. Right hand of fellowship, by the Revd. Mr Cunningham of Dorchester. 8. A Hymn by the Revd. Mr Frothingham— 9. Address to the Society, by the Revd. Mr Gannett of Boston. 10. Concluding prayer, by the Revd. Mr Huntoon of Milton. 11 An Anthem—and 12 the Benediction by Mr Lunt the installed Pastor— The performances were all creditable— Mr Frothingham’s Sermon admirable— From 1. Timothy 3.16. “And without controversy, great is the mystery of godliness: God was manifested in the flesh, justified in the spirit, seen of angels, preached unto the Gentiles, believed on in the world, received up into glory.” The principal topic of the discourse was the manifestation of God in the person of Jesus Christ; and it was illustrated in the peculiar manner, and original train of thought and splendid composition of the preacher— There were allusions in the charge, in the right hand of fellowship, and in the Address to the Society, to the present condition of religious affairs, and to the recent changes in the Constitutional Laws of the Commonwealth relating to the connection between Ministers and their Congregations. The Services closed about half past two— The House was not quite filled— The members of the Council, preceded by the Committee of the Parish, returned to French’s tavern where they dined—about fifty persons— The dinner was short— There was cyder served but no wine I presided at the table as I had been requested to do by Mr Beale for the Committee, and just before the rising from Table returned the thanks of the Society and Church, to all the members of the Council in attendance, and especially to those Gentlemen who had taken part in the performances of the day— I said it had been my fortune to be absent during the time of the transactions between the Society and the new associate Pastor which had terminated in his instalment as the Colleague of Mr Whitney this day. That I had however been informed of them from time to time as they had taken place, had approved of them all, and rejoiced exceedingly at the unanimity with which the Church and Society had agreed to invite Mr Lunt to settle with them as the Colleague of Mr Whitney— That on my return three days since to my residence, I had been requested by the Committee of Arrangements to preside at the table this day, which office, all unfitted for it as I was, I had accepted with pleasure inasmuch as it afforded me the opportunity, in the name and behalf of the Society and Church to return their thanks, to all the members of the Council for their attendance and especially to the officiating members for their very appropriate and acceptable performances— We thanked them for the Instruction which we had received from their friendly ministrations we thanked them for their kind sympathies—for their good advice, and affectionate exhortations: we thanked them for their fervent prayers and asked the continuance of them; [“]that under the manifestation of the word of God, unfolded to us as it had been in the discourse of the day, in all its magnificence and splendour, the new relations formed between the colleague of the venerable pastor who sat at my side, might permanently redound to the welfare as well temporal as spiritual of the flock, and to the glory of God, in the promotion of Christian Piety and Christian Charity”— The grace was then said by the Revd. Mr Pierpont, and the company dispersed— The President of Harvard University, Quincy, and the former President, Dr Kirkland were present. Dr Kendall
of Plymouth, and sundry others, mostly young men— Mr Frothingham came home with me, and paid a visit to our Ladies— As did Mr James H. Foster and his daughters Mary and Louisa— Mary is in very bad health, and looks as if in a deep consumption. Mr Andrew Dorr of Boston, with his Son came to make enquiries concerning a claim which he had before the Commissioners under the French indemnity Treaty of 1831. and which he said they had rejected. The ship was taken by a French privateer in 1810. under the Berlin or Milan decree— She was retaken by a british armed vessel, and carried into an English Port, and there restored to the owners upon payment of heavy salvage, and this constitutes Mr Dorr’s claim to indemnity under the Treaty with France. Mr Jeremiah Nelson is Mr Dorr’s agent for pursuing his claim before the Commissioners, but he has not informed him upon what principles it was rejected by them— I told Mr Dorr that I had heard the Treaty itself made no provision for any captures under the Berlin and Milan decrees except those cases which had been condemned after their revocation. He thought this strange— Mr Dorr told me that his brother John was still living; but that his brother Joseph whom I last saw in Paris in 1815 was dead— My Son Charles came out from Boston, and was present at the services, but not at the dinner. He returned home towards Evening. I went to the Evening party at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s— It was given to the two Ministers Mr Whitney and Mr Lunt— All the Whitney family, and almost all the Greenleafs were there—Mrs Baxter and her daughters—Edward Miller, his wife, Son and daughter, Mr Beale, his Son and daughter—Doctor Woodward, and some who to me were strangers. There was a cold Supper, with fruits of the last year— I came home between ten and eleven— My wife and Mary were not well enough to go out any part of the day.
4. IV:30. Thursday.

There was an excitement in the transactions of yesterday, which did not entirely subside at Night— I slept little, and rose this morning very early. After writing sometime I visited my garden, and particularly the Eastern close where I began last autumn the experiment of raising fruit and forest trees from the seed— There are apples, pears, peaches and oaks— A very small portion up of those that I sowed, and of those that are up, two thirds or three-fourths likely to perish—suffering already much by the drought— I continued the row of maple-seeds under the fence doubtful whether any one of them will come up— At ten O’Clock Mr Durand came, and I sat to him about two hours— Invited him to dine with us, but he was under an engagement to go this afternoon with Mr. Read to Mount Auburn. He proposed to come out and take another sitting on Saturday; and I engaged him to come at twelve O’Clock; to stay and dine with us, which he promised. And I requested him to invite Mr Read in my name to come with him, which he said he would propose— I took him with me to the top of the hill opposite my house to view the prospect of the Bay and of the surrounding Country— After dinner I reinspected my garden and Nursery; and found the last in the most indifferent condition. It is already so full of seedling plants of former years that there is nothing of the last Summer’s
sowing in it, except about half a dozen chesnut oaks— All my strawberry vines of every variety, wild and cultivated are covered with blossoms— But whenever the Strawberry vines grow and are not carefully weeded, they are smothered with red clover which it is impossible to separate from them— I had six seedling Nettle trees the berries of which I sowed in May 1830— They came up last year in May and were of very slow growth. The winter has killed them all but one which is barely alive— This evening Mr Thomas Adams came, and proposed to me a pair of Carriage horses for which the owner asks 600 dollars. I took it for consideration— He also said there had been a meeting of the inhabitants of the town who had resolved to celebrate the next 4th. of July, and had chosen a Committee of which I was chairman, to procure an Orator— I have received five Volumes of the writings of Washington, from the second to the sixth inclusive, and have begun to read them
5. IV:10. Friday.

Charles Faxon Surveyor of the highways in Braintree came this morning with a tax bill of one dollar eight Cents, being my portion of a tax raised by the town of Braintree of 1200 dollars for mending and repairing the roads— They assess me for 800 dollars, at which they estimate the part of the lawyers common which lies in Braintree and the lot that I purchased ofBaxter— Mr Ibrahim Bartlett Secretary of a Meeting of the Citizens of Quincy, held on Wednesday Evening at the town Hall, brought me a written notification of their proceedings— They voted to celebrate the approaching anniversary of the National Independence, if some suitable person can be procured to deliver an Oration—and they chose a Committee of five persons, Thomas Greenleaf, George W. Beale, John Whitney and Josiah Brigham with me, to procure an Orator, and to report at the adjournment of the Meeting, on Saturday the 13th. half past seven in the Evening. Mr Bartlett asked me if I would sell one Acre of Land, of that purchased by my father of my uncle Cranch, at the spot where the old Field, or as I call it, Trask house stood, and what price I would ask for it— I told him I would sell for a reasonable price but must make enquiry to ascertain what that would be— He said he had a large family to support and small means, and wishing to build a house preferred a retired spot, where he supposed the land would be comparatively cheap, to the positions where it is in great demand. My Son Charles came from Boston, with his daughter Louisa-Catherine; dined here, and returned early in the Evening home— His political speculation N. 7. published yesterday in the Boston Advocate has produced much excitement— I told him I wished to give him my collection of Medals and coins, and that he should undertake to arrange them and have them put up in suitable boxes and draws— There was this Evening a refreshing shower much needed— I went to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s to agree with him for a meeting of the Committee, upon the celebration of Independence day—but he had already retired to bed— I visited my garden and nursery morning and afternoon— Finished sowing the row of maple Seeds, under the Northern fence of my Eastern close—very doubtful whether any of them will ever come up— My black and red Currant bushes are in bearing—the third year from the seed.
6. IV.30. Saturday.

Morning visits to the Ladies from Mrs Tufts of Weymouth, and her daughter, and from Mrs Thomas Greenleaf and her daughter Mary Ann— The other daughter is recently married to Mr W. Appleton— Mrs Tufts said some enquiries had been made by Mr Zenas French of her Son Quincy Tufts respecting the red cedar swamp in Randolph which once belonged to Norton Quincy; and Mr Tufts wished to know whether I had any knowledge of this land— It is the same land which on the 21st. of September 1833. I visited with Zenas French; but I know little more about it. At Noon Mr Read, and Mr Durand came out from Boston. I sat again for my picture, and walked before dinner to the top of the hill opposite my house, with Mr Read, to shew him the prospect— They dined with us, and returned early after dinner to Boston— In the evening I called at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, and found Mr Beale there— They agreed to meet on Monday Evening at my House, at seven O’Clock; and Mr Beale engaged to notify Mr John Whitney and Mr Josiah Brigham, the two other members of the Committee appointed by the Citizens who resolved to celebrate the anniversary of Independence, to procure an Orator— We had some conversation upon the condition and prospects of the town of Quincy, in the increased and increasing demand for the granite, or rather Sienite Stone, which forms some of its rocks, and which is now so much used for building dwelling houses—not only in Boston, but in New-York, and New-Orleans. owning some of the land which bears this stone, there are enquiries geological, economical, and topical, which I ought to make concerning it. 1. Of the composition of the stone, and its varieties— 2. Of the number of ledges, and number of workmen, now employed upon them 3. Of the prices of the stone in its different qualities. 4. Of the different manners in which it is transported to the landing places, and thence to the places of its final destination. 5. other enquiries, to be suggested by the information obtained from the result of these.— In my garden I planted sundry peach-stones, and seeds of wintered apples, which I had collected to plant last autumn and left here when I was called away.— I began also to transfer to the last volume of my Diary, the minutes made during my late visit to Philadelphia.
7. IV. Sunday.

Heard Mr Lunt this morning from 2. Peter 1.12 “Wherefore I will not be negligent to put you always in remembrance of these things, though ye know them, and be established in the present truth”— This was an occasional discourse, upon the duties and appropriate offices of a minister of the gospel, in his relations with his parishioners extremely well written and as well delivered as a languid manner, with much occasional effort at animation would admit. It was nearly an hour long, which was more than the patience of some of the auditory could approve— Mr Lunt is said
to have parted from his former flock at New-York in consequence of some defect of activity in his social relations with his parishioners, and there appeared to be some indirect allusion to this incident in the selection of his text, and in the purport of his discourse— In promising not to be negligent of his pastoral duties he asked for an indulgent consideration of their various nature, and of the obstacles to the entire fulfilment of one class of them, arising from the necessary devotion of time to another. The preparations for weekly public worship, necessarily occupying a large portion of time, and the cares of a domestic household absorbing another, he said would leave only a remnant which could be applied to friendly visiting of the members of the Society, perhaps once or twice a year— He spoke with great respect of his Senior associate Mr Whitney, who was not present; reminded the people of his long and faithful Services, and expressed his confidence that they would ever retain, the sentiments of reverence and affection for him, which his good offices towards them as the minister of god in their exercises of public devotion, in the baptism of their children, in the solemnization of their marriages, in the last Offices of religion, over the remains of their departed relatives and friends, had so long and so amply deserved— At the close of the morning services Mr Lunt administered the communion, in which I participated, but sent the children home with Mr Beale— On coming home I found Mr Degrand, who had come out from Boston; and who dined with us, and went to meeting with me after dinner— Mr Lunt’s afternoon text was from Matthew 5.8. “Blessed are the pure in heart: for they shall see God.” A contrasted parallel, between the objects which the world account as blessings, and those which are so characterised by Jesus Christ, and an exposition of what is to be understood, by the promise that the pure in heart shall see God, formed the topics of this discourse— Mr Degrand after tea, returned to Boston. I read the tenth Sermon of the sixth volume of Saurin, upon general abuses. Applicable to all times, and all countries. We had as evening visitors Mr. and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf—E. Price Greenleaf—George Dawes and Mrs Mary Dawes—Richard C Greenleaf, Mary Whitney, and a Miss Lincoln of Hingham.
8. IV:15. Monday—

There was a frost last Night, and after attempting this morning to write I found it so cold, that I left my writing desk and repaired to my Garden, to work for exercise— Deacon Josiah Adams came and found me there, and in settling with me his rent for a pasture for two years entered into a conversation of about two hours— At nine O’Clock with Mrs Adams in a Carriole of Gillet’s driven by Wilson I went to Boston, to my Son Charles’s house, Hancock avenue number 3— Saw his second boy, born Wednesday the 27th. of May and his wife who still keeps her chamber, and was in bed. While I was there, Mr Durand came in, and Mr Read with his Son in Law, Mr Allen, to look at the Portraits— I went to Charles’s Office, which is now on the first floor of my house in Court Street; and while I was there Mr Alexander H. Everett came in, full of political speculation. Thence I went to the Athenaeum, and viewed the annual exhibition of pictures, which is inferior to those of former years— I met there Mrs Quincy and her three daughters, and a young painter by the name of Osgood— Among the Portraits was the copy by Mr Durand of the Portrait
of me which he painted last March at Washington, and of which copy Mr. C. A. Davis has made a present to my Son Charles’s wife— Returning from the Athenaeum I stop’d at Russell and Odiorne’s Book Store, and paid for the Volumes of Sparks’s Writings of Washington from 2 to 6—and the 7th. which they now delivered to me— We dined with Charles and between four and five O’Clock in the afternoon returned to Quincy—cold as winter— In the evening Thomas Greenleaf, George W. Beale and Josiah Brigham, members of the Committee for procuring an Orator for the Anniversary of Independence, met at my house— Mr John Whitney the other member of the Committee was suddenly taken ill this morning, and could not attend— After gravely discussing for about an hour the question to whom we should apply; whether to Mr Webster, to Alexander H. or Edward Everett to President Quincy, or to his Son Josiah, we finally settled upon giving an invitation to President Quincy, and I immediately wrote him a Letter, which was signed by all the members of the Committee present. Mr Webster would have been preferred; but he has just gone upon professional business to Washington—and it would have been impossible to obtain his answer in time to report at the adjournment of the Meeting next Saturday evening: Mr Brigham shocked me by the information that Mr John Bailey was dying of a consumption.
9. IV:15. Tuesday.

Alpheus Spear came this morning and settled with me, for the rent of the Mount Wollaston farm, for two Quarters, from the first of last October. He spoke to me also about building a wharf upon the Creek, and on the farm, with a road to the Stone quarries, and a road from the farm to the Neponset-Bridge road; all which if done at all must be effected in concert with Daniel Greenleaf— Spear wants it not only for the accommodation of the Stone-cutters, but for the benefit of much trade and particularly for barrelling beef, a business for which he thinks the spot advantageously situated— I promised to go and view the location, and to examine further into the subject— A dentist by the name of Baker came to offer a supply of whole sets of teeth; one of which he had in his own mouth— Mr Thomas L. Winthrop paid me a morning visit— Mr Durand came about ten O’Clock, and I sat to him about two hours— He took also a sitting of my grand daughter Georgiana Frances, at the request of Mr Read, who yesterday asked me to permit him to present the picture to me. Mr Read and his Son in Law, Mr Allen came out about Noon; and Durand returned to Boston with them before dinner— Immediately after dinner E. Price Greenleaf came, and with me visited my seedling trees in the Garden and Nursery. They are suffering severely from the drought; and many of this years shoots have already perished— The Oaks are still coming up, and under the Northern fence of the Eastern close where I had last week found 16. I yesterday discovered 20. and this Morning 25. A remarkable circumstance is that wherever I have put down a single seed or plant of strawberries, and they have spread, a patch of clover red or white invariably grows
up with them, and in many cases entirely smothers them— I leave all the weeds round my young plants now standing, as their only protection from the scorching Sun, and drought— We had an Evening visit from Mr William Eliot a Son of Mr William G. Eliot, a clerk in the Post-Office at Washington, whose wife is a daughter of Judge Thomas Dawes deceased— This young man was graduated two or three years since at the Columbia College at Washington, and has been preaching last winter at St. Louis in the State of Missouri, where he proposes to settle— He is much pleased with his situation there, and says that the Settlers there from New-England, already outnumber the French— We sent Wilson to Boston this morning and he brought out a Carriage and pair of horses which Charles has purchased for us.
10. IV:30. Wednesday.

My Son Charles came out, and brought with him his eldest boy John Quincy— I rode with Charles to the Railway house, and thence walked to the quarries of granite or Sienite Stone upon my land, which have recently been opened— There are two companies with whom he has contracted, and each of them has opened a waggon way from Mr Hall’s way, to the quarry—both have begun to work, but with different prospects of success— The rocks lie in immense masses, shelving one over another; but there are varieties in the composition of the rocks, one portion of which only is in great demand— It is that which splits in large blocks, and has a uniform appearance of darkling blue, without any vein of a rusty reddish colour; for the latter when exposed to the atmosphere exudes a dusky smoky, discolouring matter, and is in no demand except for cellar-stone. This difference of the Stone is a discovery of late years, and first became generally known by the discolouring of the Quincy Meeting House, which is very great, to the excessive disappointment and mortification of the People— There is a taste of fashion for the bluish uniform colour, which makes the difference of value between that and all the rest, as great comparatively as between that of gold and copper, or of silver and tin— The Stone-cutters who have not the conveyance of the Railway cannot work the inferior Stone to make any profit, and after blasting it out of the rock are obliged to leave it on the ground One of the quarries now opened on my land appears to yield Stone of the best quality— The other as yet has brought out none but the stained stone, and the contractors are apprehensive they shall be obliged to abandon it— There is intermingled with the Stone, suitable for building, much of other kinds—loose rocks of entirely different character; and much of that which they call pudding Stone— As we were returning, Charles spoke to Mr Bryant, the agent of the Railway company, about the places where the Railway passes through my lots and for which I never have been indemnified. He said he would mention it to the Directors of the Corporation— The President of which is Mr Cary, Son in Law to Coll. Thomas H. Perkins; and Perkins himself, Isaac P. Davis and Patrick T. Jackson are in the direction. Bryant said it was their intention to lay anew the Railway to the Bunker-Hill ledge, which is out of repair, and has been for several years abandoned— There are now in the neighbourhood of the
Railway-house, eight or ten sheds, with men at work hammering the Stone for the ornamental mouldings of the columns of the Astor house at New-York. While we were at the quarries a sudden and great change of weather took place. The morning was at high Summer heat—about noon the wind changed to the North-east, chilling cold; and brought up rain— Charles returned after dinner with his child to Boston— We had a fire in the parlour this Evening.
11. IV:15. Thursday.

Mr Durand came out at ten this Morning, and had a long sitting from me, and another from Fanny— He has got now a likeness of me, stronger than was perhaps ever before taken; and compared with that of Copley, painted in February and March 1796, is an eloquent lesson of humility— A memento mori, keen as the sword suspended over the head of Damocles. My face looks to myself like a ruin— Yet how I waste the few hours that are left me! and what a contrasted view of human life is this dilapidation, with the cherub face of the child! Mr Durand dined with us, and returned after dinner to Boston. Alexander H. Everett also came out, with my Son Charles and dined with us. He had projected to hold some conversation with me, which was interrupted by the presence of other persons. Mr Minott Thayer, General Whitney of Deerfield, and Mr Thomas Phillips of Boston, a Son of my old friend and fellow Student John Phillips, having paid me an afternoon visit— Charles and Mr Everett returned towards Evening to Boston. I received from President Quincy an answer, to the invitation from the Towns Committee, inviting him to deliver an Oration on the ensuing 4th. of July— He declines, on account of his multiplied occupations, and the weakness of his voice— I went to Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, and on consulting with him we concluded that I should write to Coll. Josiah Quincy junr, and enquire of him whether he would accept an invitation from the Committee to deliver the Oration; for that his answer may be obtained in time to report at the adjourned Meeting of the Citizens next Saturday Evening— Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf were at their brother’s— On returning home, I found Mr Lunt our newly installed Associate Minister, paying an evening visit— I received also this Morning Letters from Mr Frye and from Charles King, the latter with a New-York American, containing a Letter to him from Henry Lee at Paris, being an abusive attack upon my Oration upon the Life and character of La Fayette— Henry Lee, Benjamin Hazzard and John Armstrong, are critics about upon a level with each other, and have manifested their ambition for a controversy with me: Lee by this Letter to Charles King, Hazzard by his pamphlet upon my Letters on Masonry, and Armstrong, by a pamphlet against my Eulogy on James Monroe— I have taken no notice of either of them. Nor of Reuben M. Whitney, a worthy compeer for them all in infamy of character, and who in a memorial to Congress, did the same honour to my Report on the Bank of the United States.
12. IV:30. Friday.

I wrote a note this morning to Coll. Josiah Quincy jr. enquiring whether it would be agreeable and convenient to him to deliver an Oration in this town, on the approaching anniversary of Independence; and informing him that if it should be, he would receive an invitation to that effect from the Committee— I sent it down to his house, having heard that he and his family had come out from Boston— But it proved that they did not come out till this afternoon— My Letter was sent to him again, and towards evening he came in person, and told me that he would with pleasure deliver the Oration; but that as President of the Common Council of Boston, he should be obliged to be there on that day. I went in to Mr Beale’s, and gave him President Quincy’s answer to the invitation of the Committee, which I requested him to read, at the adjourned Meeting of the Citizens to-morrow evening, which it will not be in my power to attend— And I desired him to report also that I had written to Coll. Josiah Quincy jr. and had received from him the above answer— I had been told that many of the Citizens would be glad to hear me deliver the Oration, and I requested Mr Beale, if any such feeling should be manifested to say that I would cheerfully deliver the Oration, as I should be happy to gratify any wish of the Citizens of Quincy, but that circumstances of a domestic nature would render it a painful office at this time, it being not only the day of my father’s death, but having since the last Anniversary lost a beloved Son, who was born on that day— I did not wish explicitly to give this reason, but he might allude to it in general terms to avert any possible application to me. Alpheus Spear came this morning, and I walked with him to the beach at the Mount Wollaston farm, and viewed two places, at one of which he was desirous that a wharf should be built— This is a great undertaking which if accomplished would doubtless be very advantageous to the farm, but the expense of which might far transcend its resulting profits— A road, a mill dam, a mill, and one or more dwelling houses are among Mr Spear’s contemplated associations with the building of a wharf—about all which I must reflect and enquire much before I proceed to undertake— The best place for the wharf appears to me to be opposite the old lime trees. Returning home I saw the canal wharf covered with blocks of the granite Stone, some of which Josiah Adams junr. was casing up, to be sent to New-Orleans; upon a contract by Newcomb for the Stone of a dwelling house for 1900 dollars— They have been, nine men, about two months at work for the performance of this contract, and are just now completing it— Adams asked me what I thought of having Mr Lunt’s last Sunday morning Sermon printed— I told him, I should be much pleased with it, and would take ten copies, if it should be— There were two Sloops loading with Stone at the wharf— There was also much of the Stone, engaged for the works now in progress upon George’s Island— While I was out, Mr and Mrs Cruft from Boston were here with a young English traveller whom they introduced, said to be a relation of the Baring’s, and after dinner, my brother’s widow, Mrs Ann Adams was here— She spent the winter chiefly in New-York, at Mr De Wint’s, but has since been at Portland, Haverhill, and Medford— She returned to her house the day before yesterday.
13. IV:45 Saturday.

Mr Cary, President of the Railway Corporation, and Mr Bryant the Superintendent came this morning to speak upon the subject of their occupation of a part of my lots where the quarries of stone have been opened— The Bunker hill ledge portion of the railway crosses my Joy, Field and Savil lots, at three places, as I shewed them by the plan of Mather Withington, taken in August 1826. Mr Cary said that Coll. Thomas H Perkins, now in Europe had requested him to take his place as President of the Corporation during his absence. That the company would readily indemnify me for the taking of my land, and Mr Bryant would give the necessary attention for ascertaining by agreement with me the amount of the indemnity. Bryant proposed to wait till the approach of Winter when the trees will be without leaves, for a joint accurate survey of the boundaries to which I assented— The Bunker-hill ledge portion of the Railway is now in a state of dilapidation, but Mr Cary said the company might hereafter repair it, and resume the working of the ledge— Levi Humphrey was here, with a Braintree highway tax for the last year, which I paid— He asked me, if I did not wish to have a Stone-wall fence made on the road border of the lot I bought in 1832 of James Baxter; which he supposed necessary to preserve the growing Oaks upon the land from the intrusion of trespassing cattle— I told him I would go and view the lot, and if I should conclude to build the Wall, would let him know— He said there were eighty-one rods of Wall to make, and the cost of making it would be from 1 dollar and a quarter to a dollar and a half a rod— I went to Boston, with Mrs Adams, the child Fanny, and Mrs Wilson— We stop’d at the Athenaeum, where Mr Durand has a chamber in the upper Story of the building. He took a sitting of the child till one O’Clock, while I deposited at the Savings Bank seventy dollars, in my own name, but for the benefit of John Wilson, my Coachman, who left in my hands that sum to keep for him— I gave my Son Charles also, whom I found at his house 300 dollars in Bills, to deposit to my credit at the U.S. Branch Bank; for I have found inconvenience and danger of loss in keeping too large a sum of Bills, in my pocket-Book. I returned at one to the Athenaeum, and sat to Mr Durand till two— Mrs. Adams, with Mrs Wilson and the child had gone to Charles’s house. Mr Durand said he should want another sitting both of me and of the child, and promised to come to Quincy for that purpose, next Wednesday; and I engaged him to paint also a Portrait of my other Grand-child, Mary-Louisa, which I propose to give to her mother— At two I went with Charles to Medford, and dined at Mr Peter C. Brooks’s— It was the monthly dinner of the Trustees of the Massachusetts agricultural Society, but the company was miscellaneous— Edward Brooks, Ezekiel Hersey Derby of Salem, Commodore Downes, Edward Everett, Mr and Mrs Frothingham, Benjamin Gorham, Benjamin Guild, a young man named Hunnewell, President Quincy and his Son Josiah, Mr Stetson the Minister of the Parish, Mr John Welles and Mr Thomas L. Winthrop
were there— Mr Hunnewell is a partner of Mr Samuel Welles in business at Paris, and engaged to marry a daughter of Mr John Welles, now there; and Mr. and Mrs John Welles are going with Mr Hunnewell to France to be present at the nuptials— President Quincy spoke to me of a Memoir by Doctor James Jackson of Boston, of his Son lately deceased— We had a light thunder shower while we were at dinner, which at Boston was a heavy one, and at Quincy a flooding— I returned with Charles to Boston, and then with my wife, the child, and Mrs Wilson to Quincy. It was between nine and ten O’Clock when we reached home.
14. IV:45 Sunday.

Heard Mr Lunt, in the morning from 1. Corinthians 13.13. [“]And now abideth faith, hope, charity, those three; but the greatest of these is charity”—and in the afternoon from Psalm 3.5. [“]I laid me down and slept: I awaked; for the Lord sustained me.” Both ingenious and well written discourses— That of the morning upon a very common topic—that of the afternoon, singular and original— There is a Sermon of Dean Swift’s upon sleeping in church; which is a Satire; Mr Lunt may have intended indirect admonition to his hearers, by the selection of his subject, but it was not apparent in any part of the discourse itself— He considered Sleep, as a part of constitution of human nature—as a beneficent dispensation of Providence to Man—as furnishing by analogy an argument, in favour of the resurrection from death and the immortality of the Soul— He remarked that both in the Old and in the New Testament, Death is almost always mentioned under the name of Sleep as the kings of Israel and Judah who died of natural deaths are said to have slept with their fathers; and Saint Paul, particularly when referring to the resurrection speaks always of the dead as being asleep— And Jesus himself before raising Lazarus from the dead, said to his disciples “Our friend Lazarus sleepeth; but I go that I may awake him out of Sleep[”]— In conclusion the auditory were reminded of their obligation, whenever they enjoyed the blessing of Sleep, to employ the first moment of awaking in grateful ejaculation to the bountiful creator by whom it is bestowed— The Sermon upon Charity, considered that virtue in its most comprehensive sense, as that Love which is the highest attribute of God and which in the Scripture God himself is said to be. Mr Lunt noticed this peculiarity of the Christian and Jewish System of Religion, as distinguishing it above all others, though even in the heathen mythology he said that Love was represented as the first and most antient of all the Gods, the father of them all, and of men— He marked the distinctions between the virtues of Faith, Hope and Charity, and their relations with the several faculties of Man. Faith as the operation of Reason, Hope of the Imagination, and Charity of the Heart. He described their several properties, their influences upon the conduct, and their adaptations to the condition and to the happiness of man—concluding as he began by repeating his text—and now abideth Faith, Hope, Charity—these three— But the greatest of these is Charity. I read the eleventh Sermon of the sixth Volume of Saurin, upon the advantages of Piety, or as the English Translation of the Bible has it of godliness: and I began again to read Milman’s History of the Jews having already read heretofore great part of the first Volume— I had also
time for writing a page of Diary. We had evening visits from Mr Beale, and his daughter Ann, from Edward Miller and E. Price Greenleaf.
15. IV. Monday.

There was another sudden change of weather yesterday, about five O’Clock in the afternoon from high Summer heat to cold craving a fire— The night was cold and so was all this day though clear— Mr Carr mowed the grass in my garden, but the clover was so thick and matted that it had wholly smothered my plant of Strawberry from over the hill, and a number of my seedling trees. Mr Thomas Greenleaf came to look at my young trees in the garden and Nursery; and we went over the wall, and viewed with Mr Beale the Apple trees, from which he has been extracting the borer worms— They were in ten or twelve of his trees, several in each tree between the bark and the wood— But later in the Season they bore directly to the heart of the tree. The tenth of June is the time for eradicating them, and they are then within six inches from the surface of the ground, moving upwards. I had morning visits from Mr Jackson, the member of Congress from the 5th. district, and from the Lieutenant Governor and now acting Governor Armstrong— Mr Jackson told me he had seen Mr John Bailey last week, and never expected to see him again—that he was in the last stage of decline, with a lung fever— Mr Jackson and Mr Armstrong were both overflowing with Politics, and especially with the prospects of the next Presidential election— They both believe that according to present appearances Mr Van Buren will be elected; but are both extremely averse to taking his side— They were anxious to know my opinions which I freely gave them— Intending to be the partizan of no man myself, and believing that in point of principle there is not the weight of a feather to chuse between the candidates before the public, I told them that since the issue of the democratic Convention at Baltimore, and especially of the elections to the Legislature of Virginia, it appeared to be reduced to a certainty, as much as any event depending upon popular elections could be foreseen, that Mr Van Buren would be elected. Mr Jackson said he had last week received a Letter from Mr Slade of Vermont, who was very much opposed to Van Buren; which I attributed to the personal resentments for which Slade has had so much cause— I told him how ill Slade had been treated by Van Buren, and how much I sympathised with him in the sense of his wrongs— I added there were other things in Mr Van Buren’s treatment of me, which I had reason deeply to resent; but a public life ought to be a perpetual sacrifice of resentments— There is not a Presidential Candidate before the People at this day, who has not treated me ill. I must forgive them all— In the turbid stream of political life a consciencious man, must endeavour to do justice to all, and to return good for evil; but he must always expect a return of evil for good— Mr Armstrong is much dissatisfied with the arrangements of the triumvirate Webster, Edward Everett, and John Davis in disposing of the Government of the Commonwealth as they did, to Everett. He thinks the People of the Commonwealth will not ratify the bargain— But the People of the Commonwealth have been so managed for the last six years, that I know not how long they may be kept in their leading strings— Armstrong told me that it had
been signified to him as the wish of Mr Webster that he should preside at the Meeting at Faneuil Hall, which he had declined— He said that he felt compassion for Webster, knowing the great disorder of his private pecuniary concerns—and it was so great that he did not see how it would be possible for him to continue in public life at-all— Mr Armstrong said also something to me about the movements against foreigners in this Commonwealth, and he brought me the Reports of the Commissioners for the revisal of the Statute Laws—a work not yet completed— In the afternoon I rode with the Ladies and children over to Dorchester, and I called to see Mr Bailey— I found him sitting up, in a rocking chair, alone, feeble, emaciated, with a thick winter cloak over him, and his hands, burning with fever— Able to speak very slowly, with a hollow voice scarcely above a whisper and a sepulchral cough— I should suppose he could not continue to the end of the month, yet he spoke of his condition, as if yet susceptible of recovery. He gave me an account of his disease, from its first attack about the beginning of March, and its vicissitudes of apparent convalescence and of relapses, which have left a lingering hope with him, for which there is evidently no foundation— He said something to me of public affairs; but fearing to exhaust his strength by much conversation I abridged my visit, and promised to call shortly, and see him again— Evening at home.
16. IV. Tuesday.

James Baxter was here this morning, and I made enquiry of him concerning a mortgage, which it was said he had given to his brother of the lot of Land which I purchased of him in November 1832— He assured me there was not and never had been such a mortgage— That he had offered one to his brother, to whom he had owed 1000 dollars but he had declined taking it, and the debt was now paid— William Spear was here shortly afterwards, and seemed inclined to doubt whether there had not been such a mortgage. He said his brother Daniel, the Deacon, now deceased had told him that Baxter himself had said to him that his brother had had a mortgage, on the lot, but that he had taken it up— Spear returned to me two Deeds and a plan of a woodlot which we viewed last October, and about the bounds of which there was question made by Lemuel Brackett— He says Brackett persevered in contesting the bounds till Mr Humphrey the Surveyor went with them and viewed the lot, and settled the question against Brackett at once— I agreed to go some day next week to the lots where the ledges have been opened this Spring, and to mark the places where they are crossed by the Bunker-hill ledge railway— Harvey Field was here, and gave me a vote of the meeting of Citizens last Evening for the celebration of the Anniversary of Independence. It was a vote of thanks to the Committee, who had been appointed to procure an Orator, and discharging them from further consideration of the subject— After which another Committee was chosen for the same purpose— Mr Field made some enquiry concerning Mr Webster, and asked if I would write to him, upon his return from Washington, and invite him to deliver the Oration, which I declined— He then said that Mr Solomon Lincoln of Hingham had been mentioned, as a suitable person to deliver
the Oration; and asked if I knew him— I said I did, and that I had no doubt he would deliver a very good Oration; and would be a very proper person to apply to— He also asked if next October would not complete the century from my fathers Birthday. I said it would— We had much more conversation, upon the concerns of the Town and Parish— Mr Field is a butcher—the most active and enterprizing man in the town, and is now for the first time one of its Representatives in the Legislature of the Commonwealth— He told me that he was the first child, that Mr Whitney had christened, and that the first child christened by Mr Lunt was his Son—last Sunday evening at his house— This afternoon Mr Stephen Thayer, came with his nephew, of the same name to enquire if he could procure, for the Braintree Lyceum, a Set of the Diplomatic Correspondence, edited by Mr Sparks, and published by order of Congress— He said there were two Literary Institutions in Braintree—one the Lyceum, specially incorporated, and the other a Library, and reading room Association, according to a general corporation Law of the State acting as a corporate body— One of these has received the first set of the diplomatic correspondence in 12 Volumes, and the other the second set in seven. He wanted the first set, for the Lyceum— I desired him to send me with a written note, stating the facts with the names of the two Institutions, and I would endeavour to procure from the Clerk of the late House of Representatives of the United States, a copy of the first set for the Lyceum. In the evening I visited my brother’s widow, Mrs Ann Adams, with whom I found her Sister Mrs Greenough— I called also upon Mr Edward Miller, and there saw his mother, his wife and his daughter—
17. V. Wednesday.

A distant salute of 24 guns at Sunrise, announced this as the Bunker hill anniversary, and roused me half an hour later than the proper time from my bed. My visit to the garden was short and at ten O’Clock, Mr Durand came. He continued painting the Portrait of my Grandchild Fanny, and began upon that of Mary-Louisa— He told me that Mr Allen, the Son in Law of Mr Read, after returning with him to New-York had come back to Boston, to purchase for him some Shells, of which Mr Read is making a collection.— Mr Durand dined with us, and returned immediately after dinner to Boston— My Son Charles came out with Mr Thomas Davis and took tea with us, and returned in the Evening— Charles left with me numbers 1 and 2. of his Papers signed a Whig of the Old School, which are to be published in the Boston Centinel— He has commenced as a writer of political controversy, and has published in the Boston Advocate, a series of nine numbers of Political Speculation, under the signature of a Whig Antimason— They have already drawn considerable public attention, and these papers when published in the Centinel, will draw much more— The undertaking is perilous; for it is to counteract a prevailing torrent of popular opinion, in the place where he resides— But he has the cause of Truth, of Justice and of the Constitution— Mr Davis asked me, if there
was in any of the Latin Poets such a line as Tempora mutantur et nos mutamur in illis— I said surely there was, in Ovid; and I repeated the line Et fugiunt freno non remorante dies as immediately succeeding it— But upon consulting the Book, I found the lines “Tempora labuntur, tacitisque senescimus annis,

lg.l: Et fugiunt freno non remorante dies”— Fasti 6.770.

div.p: the first of which lines expresses the same sentiment, but in far more poetical language, and beautiful imagery— Where the other line originated— Tempora mutantur et nos mutamur in illis, I cannot recollect, nor where I read it—though it has been long familiar to my Memory— I paid an Evening visit to Mr Daniel Greenleaf.
18. IV:15. Thursday.

Passed the day without interruption of visitors; but the work of the garden and Nursery blisters my hands so that I am obliged to suspend it, and with all the failures of my plantations, I have now so large a number of seedling trees of various kinds, that I know not what to do with many of them— My nursery has the appearance of a little forest, and there is no room for any new plantation there— Three large patches of my garden, are in the same condition, and the forest trees are growing to a size which makes it necessary that they should be soon removed— In my new plantation under the Northern fence of my Eastern close the Oaks continue to come up daily— There are now 55— I opened this day my trunks of Books and papers which I sent by water from Washington— I have no room for them in my Library, and it has stimulated me to the formation of a new project of building an Office, of Stone, where my books and papers, and those of my father may be kept— I retrieved the last arrears of my Diary, and closed the last volume; in which there remain however large chasms to fill which the materials are scattered. I scarcely know where— I began upon that between 4. Septr. and 18. Octr. 1833— I commenced also the description of my collection of Coins and Medals, which I propose giving to my Son Charles— In the Evening I paid a visit to Mr Whitney.
19. IV:30. Friday— Boston— Quincy

I wrote this morning till Breakfast Time and besides the Diary of yesterday filled up one page of arrears of the last volume in September 1833— I give myself this for a morning task, through the Summer, if I can so long hold to my purpose— At ten O’Clock I went with my grand-child Mary-Louisa, and Mrs Wilson to Boston. I left them at the Athenaeum, where Mr Durand took a sitting for the Portrait of the child. I went thence to my Son Charles’s Office, and returned to him the two papers that he had prepared, on the Patronage bill which passed the Senate at their last Session and which are to be published in the Boston Centinel. I made some observations to him upon the papers, and suggested to him some ideas— But the composition is entirely his own, and he will prefer that it should so continue, as it is best that it should. He has opened to himself a controversy, the result of which it is not easy to foresee; but of which my hopes anticipate a favourable issue. And all my hopes of futurity in this world are now centered upon him, and upon his employment of his
time. I spoke to him also of the collection of coins and medals which I have given him, and which he is to arrange and assort and distribute; and to put up in an appropriate desk, with a descriptive catalogue of them to be made— And I further mentioned to him my wish to erect a small building of Stone, in which my Library may be preserved, and my fathers and my own manuscript books and papers may be kept, at least in some degree secure from fire— He made some objection to this, intending himself at some future day to build a House at Quincy, where the Library may be conveniently kept—but after some conversation with me he appeared to give up his objection, and will procure a plan and estimates for the building that I propose— I visited at Governor Armstrong’s, but he was not at home.—at Mr Thomas L Winthrop’s, and he received me— He read me a Letter from Colonela citizen of the Republic of central America, and charged as he says with a diplomatic mission to the United States— The Letter is dated at New-York, but gives an account of a city in central America, which he visited last Summer, and where he says he found the ruins of a Temple 250 yards long 200 broad, and 40 yards high— He says also that he found there some exquisitely wrought works of art—and an instrument for working in Sculpture of fine Stone— From the inspection of his discoveries in that City he infers that the American Hemisphere is the seat of the most antient civilization, and that it passed from thence to Asia, Africa and Europe— And as it was totally extinguished in America, it is now in deep decline in China and Hindostan, and to a lesser degree in Africa, and still less in Europe— I told Mr Winthrop I thought his theory hardly warranted by the facts stated in the Letter—particularly as the working instrument found by the writer was of stone, shewing the want of iron instruments— But a Temple of such dimensions surely indicates a populous country and a high degree of civilization— Mr Winthrop invited me to dine with him, but I was engaged— I returned to Charles’s House, and at four O’Clock went with him to Mr Alexander H. Everett’s where we dined— Mrs Everett and Miss Everett a niece of theirs who went with them to Spain were there; and Edward Everett, Messrs. N. Hale, B. F. Hallett, Porter, Rockwell, Speaker of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth, Thomas of Plymouth, Peabody, Stephen Whitney and one other Gentleman were the company— Most of them are members of the Committee of the State Legislature for revising the Statute Law of the Commonwealth; and they are sitting during the recess of the General Court— At seven O’Clock I returned with Charles to his house, and thence with Mary-Louisa and Mrs Wilson home to Quincy. About half the time we came through a very heavy thunder shower, with a continual glare of Lightening, a fresh gale and torrents of rain— But we landed all safe just before the Temple-bell rang nine— The morning had been fair with a promise of a beautiful day— It clouded up about 3 in the afternoon— The gust came on suddenly at the dusk of Evening— I met and spoke with judge Hall this day in the Street. Mr Durand came in to Charles’s after our return there this Evening— He will paint for Charles the Portrait of Mr. Brooks.
20. IV:40. Saturday.

I was three hours from Breakfast time till Noon in my Garden and Nursery. Filled Pot Nwith fresh Earth and planted all my remnant of old seeds, Elm, Maple, Peach, Plum, and wintered Apple— The experiment is to ascertain, if any of these will come up, in the course of the present Season— I trimmed a number of my trees; and left many of them untouched— The Oaks are yet daily coming up under the Northern fence of the Eastern close— Trimmed the Vine at the Southwest corner of the House— The clover, red and white has invaded every part of the Garden— Morning visit from President Quincy— Conversation with him, on the condition of the University, and on Politics— He says the result of the proceedings upon the disorders of the last year has been favourable, and that the discipline of the College is more effective than it had been for many years but it is apparent that he is weary of his place, and I apprehend that the mass of the Students are weary of him— He feels little interest in the politics of the day, his faculties being absorbed in the discharge of his present official duties—but there seems to be an inclination to return to the larger world and to cast off the Square cap and collegiate gown— He told me of his visit yesterday to his old preceptor of Andover, Pemberton, dying at the age of ninety, and also remembered with pride and self gratulation that the first Scholar he had ever offered for admission at Cambridge is now President of the University— My occupation for the day was writing my Diary—one page of redemption of arrears in September 1833—and progress, in the assortment and catalogue of the Coins and Medals that I have given to my Son— And teaching my grand-daughter, Mary Louisa to read. About Sunset I took a walk for exercise to the 6th. Milestone, upon the road to Neponset Bridge
21. IV:10. Sunday— Summer Solstice— Sun rose 4:27.

Heard Mr Lunt this morning from Hebrews 2:4. [“]God also bearing them witness, both with signs and wonders, and with divers miracles, and gifts of the Holy Ghost, according to his own will”? and in the afternoon from Luke 9.34. [“]While he thus spake there came a cloud and overshadowed them: and they feared as they entered the cloud. 35. And there came a voice out of the cloud saying, This is my beloved Son: hear him.” The morning discourse was principally an exposition of what he called the moral miracles of the gospel of Christ— He observed that Jesus Christ himself had rested much if not all of the faith on his gospel, which he required of his disciples, upon the evidence of the miracles that he performed— He came to improve the condition of man in the Nature of Man himself—to eradicate some of the vicious principles of his nature to call forth into action some of his latent capacities of virtue— To obtain the confidence of mankind for the fulfilment of this object, he exercised before them the power of suspending and controuling the operations of physical nature. He changed water into wine—he fed thousands with five loaves and two fishes—he exorcised evil Spirits he healed the sick—he raised the dead to life—and he received at different times the miraculous testimonial of God himself of the authenticity of his mission from him
These miraculous testimonials, continued, at and after his death, so long as they were deemed by divine wisdom necessary for the propagation of the gospel— They had ceased after the age of the Apostles—but the moral miracles of the gospel had not ceased, they were yet in operation still gradually purifying the heart and improving the condition of man— The illustrations of this position were copious and eloquent— The afternoon Sermon was not less so— It was upon the Transfiguration—one of those miraculous testimonials by the direct interposition of the Deity, to the truth of the mission of Christ— He said there was a difference of opinion among the commentators, whether this was a real transaction; or a vision or dream of the apostles, who are said to have been heavy with Sleep; while Peter is represented as speaking without knowing what he said— But the story is told in Luke as of a real transaction; and is so represented by Peter in his second Epistle— Mr Lunt made a practical application of his discourse, by representing the various evils incident to human life, as overshadowing clouds, which we may naturally fear to enter, but from the midst of every one of which may be heard a voice; saying, This is my beloved Son— Hear him. The delivery of Mr Lunt is languid, with continual efforts of animation— His composition is good, his thoughts ingenious, with more of pathos than of close logical argument— I read the 12th. Sermon of the 8th. Volume of Saurin; upon the Dedication of the French Protestant Temple at Voorburg—in 1726— It is a parallel, between the Condition of the Jews, under the Assyrian and Babylonian captivities, and that of the French refugees under the persecuting Edicts of Louis the 14th.— He directly refers to nine of those Edicts issued in the twenty years from 1669 to 1689. but even in 1726. long after the death of Louis 14. and in another Country than France, a Frenchman, himself one of the fugitives from the execrable tyranny of that king, could not speak of it with the indignation that it deserved— The tone of the Sermon is rather plaintive than resentful— Louis 14. is not named—much less treated as Tillotson treats him in his Sermons— Saurin mingles with his lamentations grateful acknowledgments to the People of Holland, for the kindness with which they had received and treated the refugees— The occasion upon which this Sermon was preached was however a full half century, after the revocation of the Edict of Nantes, and when the refugees had in reality melted down into dutchmen— I made a short tour in my garden and Nursery, and in the Evening visited Mr and Mrs John Greenleaf— Their two daughters Lucy and Mary Dawes— George Dawes, their Son Richard C. Greenleaf, and Mary Whitney were there. They have Portraits of my father and mother, in crayons, painted about the time of their Marriage in 1764. or as Mrs Greenleaf says between the birth of my Sister Smith in 1765 and mine in 1767.
22. IV:30. Monday— Sun rose 4.27.

I mark the time of the rising of the Sun, only when I see him rise— I have marked yesterday and this morning his extreme Northern declination— Its bearing from my Southmost Eastern-window, precisely as it was in 1829 when I first observed it— Perhaps if it were observed after an interval of half a century, the variation of its aspect might indicate the precession of the
equinoxes— Benjamin Bass was here and settled with me for the interest due upon his note and mortgage to the 7th. of July last year and paid interest for the delay of payment to this time— Bass is a man of good understanding, somewhat fond of discussions upon riches and poverty—occasionally touching upon Politics— I was four times in my garden this day, and spent too much time there— My common garden Strawberries were first ripe, and I planted ten red ones in Pot 16 and ten white in Pot 17. to ascertain, if they will come up this Summer. I yesterday found the ground breaking in Pot 1. in which I planted sundry seeds on the first day of this month— This day the plant put out its head— I think it is an Apple— Of the multitudes of Horse Plum Stones which I planted last Summer, I find three have come up in the tall Apple seedling patch, and one in box number 2. My Oaks still continue daily to pierce the ground— I counted 83 in the Eastern close, under its Northern fence this Morning— My writing suffers from my gardening— This Evening I called to see Mr Lunt, but he and his wife were at Mrs T. B. Adams’s, where I went and found them Mr and Mrs Edward Miller, their daughter Hannah, and another young Lady were there— I received a note from my Son Charles, saying that he proposed to come out here to-morrow afternoon with B. F. Hallett.
23. IV. Tuesday. 4:27.

My garden has been neglected for annual cultivation till the growth of weeds and self sown grass puts me to shame. I find the absolute necessity of employing a steady workman upon it and have been applied to by two men, one of whom asked 20 and the other 18 dollars a month for wages— This in an advance from 40 to 50 per cent upon the prices of the last year. My seedling trees are absorbing so much space that I must abandon my plantation experiments, or transfer the seat of them— An Apple-seed in Pot N. 4. planted 2. June, breaks ground and one pignut Hickory shews itself in the St. Germain Pear tree lot. I marked with stake and Stone the only three plum-trees that have come up from the multitudes of the Plums and Stones which I planted last Autumn— I find their leaves already perforated by insects and imagine that they are attacked at the root or in the kernel itself which forms the seed leaves— In the house I pursue the recovery of arrears of my Journal in September 1833. and hear my granddaughter Mary-Louisa read. My Son Charles came out from Boston this afternoon with Mr Hallett— The first number of his Appeal from the New to the old whigs was published this morning both in the Daily Advocate and in the Centinel— Mr Beale called upon me, and informed me that the Committee of Arrangements for the celebration of the Anniversary of Independence had voted to request me to preside on that day— I desired him to express my grateful Sense of the honour done me by the Committee, to its members; but to request that they would excuse me from that Service; for the reasons which I had mentioned to him— I said I would attend at the delivery of the Oration, and would share in the subscription for the dinner; but that the day, particularly this year was associated with so many painful associations to me and to my family that I could not share in festivities
of the anniversary with the Spirit, proper to the occasion— Mr Beale then asked if I would prepare a few Toasts, for the company, to which I consented— He mentioned also the necessity of holding a Meeting of the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School fund; concerning which I promised to speak to Mr Thomas Greenleaf their President— Coll. Quincy paid us an Evening visit— I received a Letter from Mr Frye with notice of the payment by the Treasurer of the Columbian College of one years interest due the first of June last year, upon their debt to me— He had already informed me of the payment of the Dividend upon the Franklin Insurance Company Stock— I received also a Note from Doctor George Parkman, with printed notices of Audubon’s Ornithology, and an invitation to dine with him next Friday—and an invitation to dine with the Cincinnati of Massachusetts at Concert Hall, in Boston, upon the approaching 4th. of July.
24. IV. Wednesday.

I have undertaken the last two days to labour more assiduously in writing, and to waste less time; and already feel the effects of it in weakness of eyes and debility of hand— Mrs Kirke came out yesterday from Boston to live with us again, and her husband John Kirke this day— I have engaged him for a month, to work in the Garden— Mr John W. Sullivan of Boston, Son of Deacon Sullivan, who has formed an establishment at Germantown, came this morning to make enquiries concerning the validity of titles to land in Florida, under conveyances of R. S. Hackley, derived from the grant of the king of Spain to the Duke of Alagon.— I told them they were all null and void—originally fraudulent, and expressly declared null and void by the king of Spain, in the ratification of the Treaty of cession— He asked also what was the character of the grant to Arredondo— I told him I was not able to speak with certainty of that— He enquired if persons had settled upon public Lands without regular title, whether they could be confirmed in possession by Petition to Congress. I said Congress sometimes granted rights of pre-emption, upon Petition, to irregular Settlers upon Public Lands. E. Price Greenleaf was here this Evening, and I had conversation with him upon seedling plants and trees— Of those that are newly come up, the danger from the Sun is just now commencing— Mr Greenleaf noticed two Larches, and one fir tree planted by my Son Charles some years since in my Eastern close, and which are now growing vigorously, Also an Ash, from a seed sown by me, and transplanted into the close in October 1833.— The Ash is one of the Trees best suited to raising from the seed; being of rapid growth, enduring both frost and Sun—growing with a straight stem, and little annoyed so far as I have witnessed by Insects, field mice or Squirrels— The beetle bug sometimes bites off its top, but that seems to be a necessary operation to prevent its growth by too slender a stem— I have even this day and yesterday headed down one Chesnut Oak, and four pignut hickory trees in my Summer house cellar— The bark of one of those Oaks in the cellar, shells off like the Shell bark hickory. I have six cherry-trees well laden with fruit, of which the birds have already taken a large portion— I this day planted some of the Stones in Pot NThe ground is broken in Pots 1. 2 and 4. planted 1st. and 2d. of June.
25. IV. Thursday.

Mrs Hunt, the widow of a revolutionary Pensioner came, and said she had heard that Congress had passed a Law for allowing the widows of revolutionary Pensioners to receive their Pensions and enquired if it was so— I said there had been at the last Session of Congress a proposal to that effect, but it had not become a Law. Mr Brooks and Mr Edward Everett dined with us, and returned this Evening home. Kirke began his work upon the Garden— I discovered this morning, in front of the North fence of the Eastern close a Pignut Hickory, from a nut planted last Autumn, and two Maples from the seeds which I brought from Philadelphia— The plant which broke ground on the 21st. in Pot N. 1. is also a maple, the seed of which I sowed on the first of the Month—a second came out this day— It is then ascertained that the maple-seed like the Elm-seed ripens in the Spring— At Washington and Philadelphia, from the first to the fifteenth of May—that they may be gathered in all the month of May, and that the time for sowing the seeds is then— I now regret that I did not gather ten times the quantity of seeds that I did.— I fix at twenty days, the time for the maple seed, to come up. We had this day a tart from the cherries of our garden, and a dish of very good Strawberries, the first ripe— I sowed in Pot N. 15. six large Downton Strawberries for an experiment— In the old Pear tree patch 1. from East to west I planted a heap of the cherry-stones from the trees, and of which the Robins and Catbirds had picked off the fruit— They strip the trees without compassion, and make equally free with the Strawberries. I have found 24 seedling Oaks up, along the Eastern fence of my Nursery—and shall have about 150 seedling Oaks of the present Season— Their most dreaded enemy now is the Sun—there will probably not be ten of them to survive the next Winter— The suffering of my eyes, makes me waste more time upon my plantations— Mr Edward Livingston has arrived from France, at New York— I am reading the second Volume of Sparks’s Edition of the writings of Washington.
26. IV. Friday— Boston— George Parkman’s— Quincy.

I went to Boston alone, and called at the Athenaeum to see Mr Durand— The child Mary-Louisa was to have gone with me, but the weather being damp, and threatening rain, her mother and grandmother thought it best that she should not go— The inflammation in her eye is yet troublesome— Harvey Field came this morning, and gave me tickets for the dinner at the celebration of the anniversary of Independence for President Quincy, and his Son, Coll. Josiah, for Alexander H. Everett, and for my Son Charles— He said there would be 300 persons at the dinner, which is to be under a Pavilion, upon the lot given by my father to the Town, called the Hancock lot— He intimated that there was some dissatisfaction, of some of the members of the first Committee appointed to procure an Orator, that they had been discharged and another Committee chosen, but he said it was not intended to offend the first Committee— I assured him that it had given no offence to me—that if I had been present at the first meeting I should have asked owing to the particular
circumstances of my family to be excused, and after failing in the application to President Quincy and his Son, I was glad to be relieved from further service on the Committee— That I was glad they had obtained the consent of Solomon Lincoln to deliver the Oration, and should have very cheerfully applied to him had his name occurred to me or to any other member of the first Committee— He said that the reason for changing the Committee was the belief that two of its members, Brigham and John Whitney were averse to having any celebration at-all— He asked me, if I would write a hymn, for the celebration— I said I had once performed that service, and thought it would be best to have it now by some other person— In Boston, Mr Durand took of me a last sitting, of about a quarter of an hour. He said he proposed to leave the City on his return to New-York next Tuesday. I saw the Portrait of Mr P. C Brooks, which he is painting for my Son Charles, and which is nearly finished— I paid visits at Mr Edward Cruft’s and Mr James H. Foster’s— Mr Cruft gave me a rapid account of his rapid travels on a tour of seven months last year, to England, Scotland, the Netherlands, Germany, France, and Switzerland— He shewed me also his garden, his vines and his fruit-trees. The garden is a square spot, I think about eighty-feet square; with high-buildings on every side, and thus protected from all the winds— He has a few fine Plum, Apricot, and Pear trees, and Currant-bushes in excellent order, as well as vines well trellissed. He has Peach-trees trained to the wall, in a Southern aspect, but they bear this year little fruit. At Mr Foster’s I saw Mrs Foster, Louisa C. Smith and Louisa and Mary Foster— Mr Alexander H. Everett was not at home— At Charles’s Office I read numbers 3 and 4 of his appeal from the new to the old whigs— At his house, saw his wife, and his children Louisa-Catherine, and John Quincy—the baby was asleep.— Dined at Dr George Parkman’s with a mixed company—Mr and Mrs Joseph Coolidge junr. Alexander H. Everett, Mr Greenwood the Minister, two Spaniards, names unknown, a Gentleman, and two young Ladies of the Parkman family—R. G. Shaw, the Revd. Dr Tuckerman, and a Son of Dr Warren, recently returned from Europe— Coolidge has been living nearly three years at Canton in China, and intends soon to return there— I called again at Charles’s House and returning thence reached home after eight, at dusk of Evening.
27. IV. Saturday.

Fog, and alternately a drizzling mist the whole day, with rain to wet the feet, but barely sufficient to moisten the surface of the ground— Mr Nathan Read, of Belfast in the State of Maine had been here yesterday, while I was at Boston, and called again before breakfast this morning— Mr Read supposes that he has invented, an improvement upon the Construction of Boilers and Steam-Engines, to prevent the bursting of the Boilers—of which the instances are so frequent and so fatal. He said the explosions almost always happened when the Steamer was not on motion—usually just after she came to a landing. Its occasion was generally, was the boilers being drained of water, and heated to red heat. His invention was a float upon a cylinder, to rise and fall with the rotation of the paddle wheels, and open and close a valve to keep
always a supply of water in the Boiler, sufficient to prevent its bursting. Mr Read had several diagrams, upon which he pointed out to me the operation of his invention as intended by him; not however so clearly as to make it fully intelligible to me, and he admitted that it would somewhat diminish the speed of the boat— He was desirous of making his invention known by offering it to the Government of the United States, if they would undertake to make the experiment— I advised him to wait for the next Session of Congress— The danger of explosion of Steamboat boilers has already been a subject of discussion in the House of Representatives of the United States, to which an elaborate report upon it was made by a Committee at a former Session;
