but no Legislation concerning it has yet ensued— It will probably be resumed at the next Session, and I advised Mr Read to have a model of his invention made shewing the operation of it to supply the Boiler constantly with water, to take out a Patent for it, and then to make communication of it to Congress, when they shall be engaged in making provision against these disastrous accidents by Law— He said he would follow this advice— Mr Read, was the Tutor of my Class, at the University— He must be now near seventy-five years of age—he has a turn for mechanical inventions, and has busied his whole life upon them, with little profit to himself, and not much benefit to the world— He was for some years a member of Congress, but has long been retired from public life, and bears upon his countenance the marks of age— About sixteen years ago, I saw him at Washington, taking out a Patent for some other invention, and then he borrowed money of me to pay for his board and travelling expenses, which it took him two or three years to repay— He is an honest, intelligent, learned, ingenious man, with faculties to invent Steam-engines, and to be pinched with hunger for bread— He thinks that Fulton stole his Steam boat from him; and he shewed me two certificates, one of them from a Committee of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and signed by Richard Cranch, Joseph Willard, Loammi Baldwin, and another, dated in April 1790. that they had examined an invention presented by Mr Read, for propelling boats by water or carriages by Land by the means of Steam, and expressing a favourable opinion of its practicability, and of its usefulness— The other certificate was dated at New-York, about the same time, and had reference to the first Patent Law then preparing in Congress. Mr Read said that there was a Section in the Act as first prepared providing for a limitation of the profits made by any invention, if they should become exorbitant; and that at his expostulation against it that it was struck out— The weather confined me much to the house, though I visited my garden Nursery and Eastern close so as to wet my feet uncomfortably— I received a Letter from A. H. Everett, B. B. Thatcher and E. Weston junr. in behalf of the Managers of the Boston Lyceum, inviting me to deliver a Lecture before the Members of that Institution some time in October next—and towards Evening I received a Letter from Doctor John T. Spooner dated at Dorchester this day, and informing me of the decease of my highly valued friend John Bailey— He died yesterday morning, and is to be buried from Mr Cunningham’s Meeting house, at four O’Clock next Monday afternoon. He was a man of excellent principles and sound understanding—and one of my most steadfast unwavering friends. I deeply lament his loss to his family, and to the public.
28. IV.30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Lunt this morning from John 1.17.—“Grace and Truth came by Jesus Christ.” A parallel between the Christian Religion and others— A forcible remark in this Discourse was the simplicity of the Christian system as it appears in the new Testament compared with the complication and casuistry of the Sectarians called the Fathers of the Church, and of Calvinism— He noted especially the small number of precepts of which the gospel consists— This is true— The Mission of Christ had two objects—Glory to God—Good will to Man— It brought Life and immortality to light— It taught the immortality of the Soul, and the responsibility of man to a future state of existence, as articles of Faith—and assuming that as a Foundation, it taught Love to God, and Love to his fellow creature, as comprizing the whole duty of Man— It said to the human being—God is your Father—Man is your brother—Your duty to God, is filial affection and obedience—your duty to man is brotherly Love— This is simple, comprehensive and sublime— There is no metaphysical mystification in this— But in St. Paul’s argumentative Epistles, and in St. John’s Platonic musings, there is the foundation of all the metaphysical subtleties of subsequent ages. There has also been great misapprehension of the figurative language of Christ— Transubstantiation, is the mere taking in a literal sense, that which was spoken as a metaphor. So is regeneration—so is the doctrine of the atonement— The divinity of Christ is more directly asserted by St. John and St. Paul, than by Jesus himself— He claimed to be the Son of God—but this too was a metaphor— He said, before Abraham was “I am”— His language concerning himself was not so clear or so simple as his precepts— His religion is all divine— Mr Whitney preached in the afternoon, from 1. Timothy 1.17. “Now unto the King eternal, immortal, invisible, the only wise God, be honour and glory for ever and ever, Amen[”]— A unitarian Sermon—composed apparently with more meditation than Mr Whitney has been accustomed to bestow upon his Pulpit exercises— He divided the discourse into the consideration of the several attributes of God, as enumerated in the text, and the consolations to be derived from them in the conduct of human life—dwelling impressively upon the words “the only wise God,” as decisive of the divine Unity— The morning was lowering, but the Sky cleared up, and I took Fanny to Meeting with me after dinner— I read the 13th. Sermon of the 6th Volume of Saurin—upon the affliction of the righteous, occasioned by the Sins of the wicked— The preacher sets out by stating that People generally understand the obligation of Sinners, to mourn for their own transgressions; but that very few are aware of the duty of suffering affliction for the Sins of others, and he presents David, as having furnished the most illustrious example of both these kinds of affliction— He says that in contemplation of human reason it is liable to much controversy, whether a virtuous man enjoys more happiness in the present life, than the wicked; but that the Holy Spirit has decided that godliness has the promises of this life, and that if there are exceptions to this principle, they are
not in the conscience of the virtuous— In considering the fate which awaits the wicked in the future world, and the affliction which this might shed upon the upright, he is met with the objection, how the felicity of the virtuous can be perfect, if they must witness the sufferings of the wicked whom they loved, and with whom they had ties of consanguinity upon Earth— His answer to this difficulty is not satisfactory— He says that the happiness of the next world, will be the result of order, and will therefore not be disturbed by any punishment of the wicked for disorderly guilt— I hope there is better warrant for the future happiness of the good than this— I read also some pages of Milman’s History of the Jews;—paid an Evening visit to Mr Lunt, who I found with Mrs Lunt, at home. On my return I found Mr Beale, and his daughter— Coll. and Mrs Quincy, and Miss Abigail Quincy had also been here.
29. III:50. Monday— Sun rose 4:29— He has visibly gained southing.

My wife went to Boston this morning with our grand daughter Mary-Louisa, to give a last sitting to Mr Durand— They dined at my Son Charles’s and returned this Evening. At four O’Clock this afternoon I attended the funeral of Mr John Bailey, which was from Mr Cunningham’s Meeting house at Dorchester. The funeral service was performed by Mr Ritchie, formerly Minister at Canton, and of whose church Mr Bailey was a member— The service consisted in the reading of the 15th. Chapter of the 1st of Corinthians from the 35th. verse to the end of the chapter, and a prayer— There was then a procession to the burying ground in Milton, where the body was deposited in a tomb. The father of Mr Bailey was present, and three of his five children: a boy and two girls— I first became acquainted with Mr Bailey in September 1817—after my last return from Europe, when I entered upon the duties of the Department of State. I appointed him a Clerk in that Department— He had been before that time a member of the Massachusetts Legislature, and a Professor at the College in Providence Rhode-Island— He served six years in the Department of State, and was then elected a member of the House of Representatives of the United States for Norfolk District; Massachusetts— The House vacated his election upon the absurd pretence that he was at the time when elected a Clerk in an Executive Department— The People of the District immediately re-elected him, and the House then received him— He was afterwards re-elected to three successive Congresses, until 1831. He has since been two years a member of the Senate of the Commonwealth from the County of Norfolk, and was the Anti-Masonic Candidate for Governor this present year— He was a man of excellent principles, of sound understanding, and of benevolent character. Purely republican, and devoted to Liberty and good Government— He had taken an active part in the principal political controversies of the last twenty-five years; but always with great moderation— Shortly before his election to Congress and while in the Department of State, he had married Miss Young, a niece of Moses Young, who had also been a Clerk in the Department of State— She was of an Irish family; her father having been a brother of Moses Young, at whose invitation they all came to this Country, about the year 1820— Mr Bailey leaves five children. His wife has been for two or three years threatened with pulmonary consumption, and little
expected to survive him— He took his death, by exposure, in the exertions to save the house in which he lived from a fire, with which it was in danger from the conflagration of a factory in its neighbourhood about the first of March last— Mr Bailey was in the 53d. year of his age— He was one of the warmest and most faithful of my friends. I feel his loss, as of a brother— After the funeral, I went by invitation to the house of Mr Joseph Morton, where several of the Antimasons from Boston, took tea—Mr and Mrs B. F. Hallett, Dr Abner Phelps, Dr Bates, Mr and Miss Gassett, and some others were there— Mr Morton has a well cultivated garden, and a large number of thrifty fruit trees.— His cherries just ripening— Mr Edward Everett, and Dr Thompson of Charlestown were at the funeral, in the Church, but did not go to the grave-yard, nor to Mr Morton’s— I came home about 8 O’Clock.
30. III.45. Tuesday.

On this last day of the month, I took note of the seedling plants up under the Northern fence of my Eastern close and found 104 Oaks. 22 Apple-trees, 19 Pears, 1 Pignut, and 5 grape-vines, with 8 Maples of the seed that I brought from Philadelphia and sowed in the first week of this month— About one in ten of the trees is already perishing, and the Sun and drought of the two succeeding months will thin them down to less than half their numbers— There are also 7. Peach trees, from 12 to 6 inches high—none of the rest have reached more than three inches— Three of the Oaks and one Maple have appeared since yesterday morning— I found also two seedling Oaks up in the plats where I had horse-chesnuts and elms set out last October— I headed down, in the garden a very fine cherry tree of the fifth year, for a bud inserted into it last Summer by Price Greenleaf, and which looks alive— The experiment has failed upon another which I headed down about a fortnight since— I was in the garden and Nursery morning and afternoon— The red cherries are ripe, and chiefly gathered— So are the Strawberries, excepting those which have been choaked by weeds and clover— Eliakim Turner came this morning to borrow money of me, but I had none to lend. My wife was unwell, confined to her chamber— I finished transcribing my diary minutes from 4. September to 18. October 1833. into my last Volume— This has been my occupation for the month now expiring; and there are upwards of 200 pages in the same volume yet to be filled up— I can do nothing better. I received this morning a Letter for Mrs T. B. Adams, from her Son the Cadet at West-Point, and towards Evening took it to her, at her house— Met there Mr Edward Miller, who was inviting her to a Strawberry and cherry-party at his house this Evening— We went accordingly, and found there Mr and Mrs Thomas Greenleaf and their daughter Mary Ann, Mr and Mrs Daniel Greenleaf, Mr Beale and his daughter Ann, Coll. Josiah Quincy, and Doctor Woodward. Mr Lunt afterwards came in— The Strawberries were so fine, that I longed for some of them for seed— I desired Coll. Quincy to ask his father to attend a meeting of the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School fund, at my house on Saturday, the 11th. of next Month at One O’Clock, and to dine with me afterwards— I gave the same
invitation to Mr. Thomas Greenleaf, Mr Beale, and Mr Miller, the other Supervisors of the fund— Walked home, in company with Coll. Quincy— Mrs T. B. Adams had been to Boston, to meet Mrs De Wint, who comes on a visit to her friends here, and is now at Mrs Pickman’s in Boston.

Day. I rise between four and five O’Clock, intending to rise at four— Read four chapters of Thomson’s Translation of the Septuagint; write in this Diary, the Journal of the preceding day—and a half page or page of arrears in the last Volume— Visit my Eastern close Breakfast between eight and nine— Visit again my garden and Nursery, where unless interrupted by Visitors I waste from two to three hours, in looking at my seedling plants and the weeds that smother them— Then resume the writing upon arrears of my Journal and read Newspapers till dinner between two and three— After dinner I visit again my garden for half an hour or an hour— Sometimes write again arrears of Diary and read books or pamphlets, with an occasional nap till tea time, six O’Clock— Visit my Quincy neighbours for an hour or two of the Evening or spend them with my wife and daughter till the town bell rings at nine O’Clock— Soon after which we all retire— I hear my Granddaughters read sometimes before and sometimes after dinner, but that exercise has during the present month been too often intermitted.
